helpful to know where precision loss can take place. This lint can help find
those places in the code.
docs.Example:
```rust
let x = u64::MAX; x as f64
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for references in expressions that use
auto dereference.
docs.Why is this bad:
The reference is a no-op and is automatically
dereferenced by the compiler and makes the code less clear.

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `x >= y + 1` or `x - 1 >= y` (and `<=`) in a block
docs.Why is this bad: Readability -- better to use `> y` instead of `>= y + 1`.
docs.Example:
```rust
x >= y + 1
```

Could be written:

```rust
x > y
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for large size differences between variants on
`enum`s.
docs.Why is this bad:
Enum size is bounded by the largest variant. Having a
large variant
can penalize the memory layout of that enum.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `enum-variant-size-threshold: u64`: The maximum size of a emum's variant to avoid box suggestion (defaults to `200 `).

docs.What it does:
Checks for calls to `std::mem::drop` with a value
that derives the Copy trait
docs.Why is this bad:
Calling `std::mem::drop` [does nothing for types that
implement Copy](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/fn.drop.html), since the
value will be copied and moved into the function on invocation.
docs.Example:
```rust
let x:i32 = 42;   // i32 implements Copy
std::mem::drop(x) // A copy of x is passed to the function, leaving the
// original unaffected
```

docs.What it does: Checks for binding a unit value.
docs.Why is this bad:
A unit value cannot usefully be used anywhere. So
binding one is kind of pointless.

docs.What it does:
Checks for functions taking arguments by value, but not
consuming them in its
body.
docs.Why is this bad:
Taking arguments by reference is more flexible and can
sometimes avoid
unnecessary allocations.
docs.Known problems:
* This lint suggests taking an argument by reference,
however sometimes it is better to let users decide the argument type
(by using `Borrow` trait, for example), depending on how the function is used.

docs.What it does: Nothing. This lint has been deprecated.
docs.Deprecation reason:
This used to check for `.to_string()` method calls on values
of type `&str`. This is not unidiomatic and with specialization coming, `to_string` could be
specialized to be as efficient as `to_owned`.

docs.What it does: Checks for unnecessary double parentheses.
docs.Why is this bad:
This makes code harder to read and might indicate a
mistake.

docs.What it does:
Checks for trivial [regex](https://crates.io/crates/regex)
creation (with `Regex::new`, `RegexBuilder::new` or `RegexSet::new`).
docs.Why is this bad:
Matching the regex can likely be replaced by `==` or
`str::starts_with`, `str::ends_with` or `std::contains` or other `str`
methods.
docs.Example:
```rust
Regex::new("^foobar")
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for looping over the range of `0..len` of some
collection just to get the values by index.
docs.Why is this bad:
Just iterating the collection itself makes the intent
more clear and is probably faster.

docs.What it does: Checks for loops which have a range bound that is a mutable variable
docs.Why is this bad: One might think that modifying the mutable variable changes the loop bounds

docs.What it does: Checks for functions with too many parameters.
docs.Why is this bad:
Functions with lots of parameters are considered bad
style and reduce readability (“what does the 5th parameter mean?”). Consider
grouping some parameters into a new type.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `too-many-arguments-threshold: u64`: The maximum number of argument a function or method can have (defaults to `7 `).

docs.What it does: Checks for transmutes from an integer to a `bool`.
docs.Why is this bad: This might result in an invalid in-memory representation of a `bool`.

docs.What it does: Checks for unused written/read amount.
docs.Why is this bad:
`io::Write::write` and `io::Read::read` are not
guaranteed to
process the entire buffer. They return how many bytes were processed, which
might be smaller
than a given buffer's length. If you don't need to deal with
partial-write/read, use
`write_all`/`read_exact` instead.

docs.What it does: Checks for patterns in the form `name @ _`.
docs.Why is this bad:
It's almost always more readable to just use direct
bindings.

docs.What it does: Checks for statements which have no effect.
docs.Why is this bad:
Similar to dead code, these statements are actually
executed. However, as they have no effect, all they do is make the code less
readable.

docs.What it does:
Detects type names that are prefixed or suffixed by the
containing module's name.
docs.Why is this bad: It requires the user to type the module name twice.

docs.What it does:
Checks for calls to `.or(foo(..))`, `.unwrap_or(foo(..))`,
etc., and suggests to use `or_else`, `unwrap_or_else`, etc., or
`unwrap_or_default` instead.
docs.Why is this bad:
The function will always be called and potentially
allocate an object acting as the default.
docs.Example:
```rust
foo.unwrap_or(String::new())
```
this can instead be written:
```rust
foo.unwrap_or_else(String::new)
```
or
```rust
foo.unwrap_or_default()
```
docs.Known problems:
If the function has side-effects, not calling it will
change the semantic of the program, but you shouldn't rely on that anyway.

docs.What it does: Checks for non-ASCII characters in string literals.
docs.Why is this bad:
Yeah, we know, the 90's called and wanted their charset
back. Even so, there still are editors and other programs out there that
don't work well with Unicode. So if the code is meant to be used
internationally, on multiple operating systems, or has other portability
requirements, activating this lint could be useful.
docs.Example:
```rust
let x = "Hä?"
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for usage of `write!()` / `writeln()!` which can be
replaced with `(e)print!()` / `(e)println!()`
docs.Why is this bad: Using `(e)println! is clearer and more concise

docs.What it does: Checks for creation of references to zeroed or uninitialized memory.
docs.Why is this bad: Creation of null references is undefined behavior.

docs.What it does: Nothing. This lint has been deprecated.
docs.Deprecation reason:
`Range::step_by(0)` used to be linted since it's
an infinite iterator, which is better expressed by `iter::repeat`,
but the method has been removed for `Iterator::step_by` which panics
if given a zero

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `*&` and `*&mut` in expressions.
docs.Why is this bad:
Immediately dereferencing a reference is no-op and
makes the code less clear.
docs.Known problems:
Multiple dereference/addrof pairs are not handled so
the suggested fix for `x = **&&y` is `x = *&y`, which is still incorrect.

docs.What it does: Checks for transmutes from an integer to a float.
docs.Why is this bad: This might result in an invalid in-memory representation of a float.

docs.What it does: Checks for calls of `unwrap[_err]()` that will always fail.
docs.Why is this bad: If panicking is desired, an explicit `panic!()` should be used.
docs.Known problems:
This lint only checks `if` conditions not assignments.
So something like `let x: Option<()> = None; x.unwrap();` will not be recognized.

docs.What it does: Checks for comparisons to unit.
docs.Why is this bad:
Unit is always equal to itself, and thus is just a
clumsily written constant. Mostly this happens when someone accidentally
adds semicolons at the end of the operands.
docs.Example:
```rust
if { foo(); } == { bar(); } { baz(); }
```
is equal to
```rust
{ foo(); bar(); baz(); }
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for `if` conditions that use blocks to contain an
expression.
docs.Why is this bad:
It isn't really Rust style, same as using parentheses
to contain expressions.
docs.Example:
```rust
if { true } ..
```

docs.What it does: Checks for `for` loops over `Result` values.
docs.Why is this bad:
Readability. This is more clearly expressed as an `if
let`.
docs.Example:
```rust
for x in result { .. }
```

This should be
```rust
if let Ok(x) = result { .. }
```

docs.What it does:
The lint checks for `if`-statements appearing in loops
that contain a `continue` statement in either their main blocks or their
`else`-blocks, when omitting the `else`-block possibly with some
rearrangement of code can make the code easier to understand.
docs.Why is this bad:
Having explicit `else` blocks for `if` statements
containing `continue` in their THEN branch adds unnecessary branching and
nesting to the code. Having an else block containing just `continue` can
also be better written by grouping the statements following the whole `if`
statement within the THEN block and omitting the else block completely.

docs.What it does:
Checks for `if/else` with the same body as the *then* part
and the *else* part.
docs.Why is this bad: This is probably a copy & paste error.

docs.What it does: Checks for use of `&Box<T>` anywhere in the code.
docs.Why is this bad:
Any `&Box<T>` can also be a `&T`, which is more
general.
docs.Example:
```rust
fn foo(bar: &Box<T>) { ... }
```

Better:

```rust
fn foo(bar: &T) { ... }
```

docs.What it does: Checks for usage of `ok().expect(..)`.
docs.Why is this bad:
Because you usually call `expect()` on the `Result`
directly to get a better error message.
docs.Example:
```rust
x.ok().expect("why did I do this again?")
```
docs.Known problems: The error type needs to implement `Debug`

docs.What it does:
Checks for loops on `y.into_iter()` where `y` will do, and
suggests the latter.
docs.Why is this bad: Readability.

docs.What it does:
Checks for match which is used to add a reference to an
`Option` value.
docs.Why is this bad: Using `as_ref()` or `as_mut()` instead is shorter.

docs.What it does: Warns if there is a better representation for a numeric literal.
docs.Why is this bad:
Especially for big powers of 2 a hexadecimal representation is more
readable than a decimal representation.
docs.Configuration:
This lint has the following configuration variables:

* `literal-representation-threshold: u64`: The lower bound for linting decimal literals (defaults to `16384 `).

docs.What it does: Checks for iteration that is guaranteed to be infinite.
docs.Why is this bad:
While there may be places where this is acceptable
(e.g. in event streams), in most cases this is simply an error.
docs.Example:
```rust
repeat(1_u8).iter().collect::<Vec<_>>()
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for (in-)equality comparisons on floating-point
value and constant, except in functions called `*eq*` (which probably
implement equality for a type involving floats).
docs.Why is this bad:
Floating point calculations are usually imprecise, so
asking if two values are *exactly* equal is asking for trouble. For a good
guide on what to do, see [the floating point
guide](http://www.floating-point-gui.de/errors/comparison).
docs.Example:
```rust
const ONE == 1.00f64
x == ONE  // where both are floats
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for expressions where a character literal is cast
to `u8` and suggests using a byte literal instead.
docs.Why is this bad:
In general, casting values to smaller types is
error-prone and should be avoided where possible. In the particular case of
converting a character literal to u8, it is easy to avoid by just using a
byte literal instead. As an added bonus, `b'a'` is even slightly shorter
than `'a' as u8`.
docs.Example:
```rust
'x' as u8
```

A better version, using the byte literal:

```rust
b'x'
```

docs.What it does:
Checks for calls to `.expect(&format!(...))`, `.expect(foo(..))`,
etc., and suggests to use `unwrap_or_else` instead
docs.Why is this bad: The function will always be called.
docs.Example:
```rust
foo.expect(&format("Err {}: {}", err_code, err_msg))
```
or
```rust
foo.expect(format("Err {}: {}", err_code, err_msg).as_str())
```
this can instead be written:
```rust
foo.unwrap_or_else(|_| panic!("Err {}: {}", err_code, err_msg))
```
or
```rust
foo.unwrap_or_else(|_| panic!(format("Err {}: {}", err_code, err_msg).as_str()))
```
docs.Known problems:
If the function has side-effects, not calling it will
change the semantic of the program, but you shouldn't rely on that anyway.

docs.What it does:
Checks for C-like enumerations that are
`repr(isize/usize)` and have values that don't fit into an `i32`.
docs.Why is this bad:
This will truncate the variant value on 32 bit
architectures, but works fine on 64 bit.
docs.Example:
```rust
#[repr(usize)]
enum NonPortable {
    X = 0x1_0000_0000,
    Y = 0
}
```

docs.What it does: Checks for impls of `From<..>` that contain `panic!()` or `unwrap()`
docs.Why is this bad: `TryFrom` should be used if there's a possibility of failure.
